response.name: internal_intercostals
response.feedback: Correct. The internal intercostals depress the ribs which helps to further decrease the volume of the thoracic cavity.

response.name: external_intercostals
response.feedback: Incorrect. The external intercostals raise the ribs which increases the volume of the thoracic cavity during forced inspiration.

response.name: relax
response.feedback: Incorrect. During normal expiration the muscles are relaxing but when extra air needs to be forced out other muscles must participate to further decrease the volume of the lungs.

response.name: contract
response.feedback: Correct. During normal expiration the muscles are relaxing but during forced expiration muscles such as the abdominal muscles and internal intercostals contract to further reduce the volume of the thoracic cavity which increases the pressure forcing more air out of the lungs.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.

body.p: In a situation such as screaming, the process of expiration becomes process that primarily relies on the of the . By the volume of the thoracic cavity, the pressure allowing air to the lungs.

response.name: passive
response.feedback: Correct. Passive means that the muscles are relaxing which does not require energy. During expiration, the diaphragm and the external intercostals relax.

response.name: active
response.feedback: Incorrect. Active means that the muscles are contracting which requires energy.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.

response.name: contraction
response.feedback: Incorrect. When muscles such as the diaphragm and external intercostals contract they become shorter which increases the volume of the thoracic cavity.

response.name: relaxation
response.feedback: Correct. When muscles such as the diaphragm and the external intercostals relax they return to their original length which decreases the volume of the thoracic cavity.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.

response.name: diaphragm
response.feedback: Correct. The diaphragm is the muscle that is primarily responsible for inspiration. The diaphragm will relax decreases the volume of the thoracic cavity.

response.name: external_intercostals
response.feedback: Incorrect. Although the external intercostals play an important role in increasing the volume of the thoracic cavity during inspiration, they are not the primary muscle.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.

response.name: increasing
response.feedback: Incorrect. As the diaphragm and external intercostals contract they shorten and increase the volume of the thoracic cavity.

response.name: decreasing
response.feedback: Correct. As the diaphragm and external intercostals contract they shorten which actually increases the volume of the thoracic cavity because the external intercostals pull the chest walls out and the diaphragm flattens also increasing the volume of the thorax.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.

response.name: increase
response.feedback: Correct. Pressure and volume have an inverse relationship. As the volume increases the pressure will decrease.

response.name: decrease
response.feedback: Incorrect. Pressure and volume have an inverse relationship. As the volume increases the pressure will decrease.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.

response.name: enter
response.feedback: Incorrect. Air will flow from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure. During expiration, the volume of the thoracic cavity decreases which increases the pressure of the lungs.

response.name: exit
response.feedback: Correct. Air will flow from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure. During expiration, the volume of the thoracic cavity decreases which increases the pressure of the lungs above the atmospheric pressure allowing air to exit the body.

part.hint: Remember to refer to the picture and that volume and pressure are inversely related.
